The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Re: Purchase of Fuel Oil -
Caughnawaga Indian Agency.

In reply to your letter of the 31st of August, in connection with the above matter, I wish to transmit you herewith, as requested, a requisition for the quantities of fuel oil required for Government owned buildings at this Agency.

Encl. (1)

Frs. Brisebois,
Supt. of Indian Agency.

JAL/
October 18th, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Purchase of Fuel Oil - Caughnawaga Indian Agency

With reference to our telephone conversation of this morning, I attach for your information a copy of our letter of August 31st to Superintendent Brisebois.

I also attach a requisition for fuel oil which has just been received from Mr. Brisebois today. We now have 3 residences on the Caughnawaga Reserve, 1 for the teachers of the R.C. School, 1 for the teachers of the U.C. School, and 1 for the manual training instructor.

Mr. Brisebois does not state either on his requisition or his letter accompanying it where he obtained the prices quoted on the requisition.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

We have your Voucher No. 1062 covering the cost of coal supplied to the above school and teacher's residence. On Purchase Order 45451 we ordered 15 tons (30,000 lbs.) of chestnut coal for the teacher's residence. The account requests payment for 33,480 lbs.

The Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo dealing with Voucher No. 1062 and more particularly to P.O. 45451 on which 15 tons of chestnut coal had been ordered for the teacher's residence.

It is noted that 33,480 lbs. were delivered instead of 30,000 and in this connection I wish to say that Mr. Lecotot, the merchant who supplied the coal, states that our coal was delivered from the Montreal West R.R. Station, and that the truck driver who delivered same thought that owing to the fact that there was only 3,348 lbs. than the order called for he took upon himself to deliver same into the bin of the R.C. residence.

To take this coal out from the bin at the present would entail considerable expense as he would have to send a truck from St. Isidore, a distance of 12 miles.

The merchant was told that in future the quantities should not exceed those mentioned on Purchase Orders.

(sgd) F. Brisebois
Supt. Indian Agency

Ottawa, December 12, 1947.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois, Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

We had a visit yesterday afternoon from Mrs. Beauvais, mother of Leslie Beauvais. In official letter of August 29th, 1947, we authorized a tuition grant of $200. for this boy to enable him to attend Victoriaville College during the current academic year.

The mother now advises us that the boy left Victoriaville about the middle of October and the parents returned him to Pointe aux Trembles Institute where he formerly attended.

We are advised that while the mother is a Catholic, the father is a Protestant and according to the mother's story, both parents now consider that the boy should remain in Pointe aux Trembles Institute. They request that the grant at the rate of $20.00 a month promised to him when he went to Victoriaville, should be paid him at Pointe aux Trembles.

Please let me have your recommendation in the matter. Is this boy taking the high school course at Pointe aux Trembles. When he attended this institution previously he was only in the elementary grades.

Bernard E. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

December 16, 1947.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant in which you inform that the mother of Leslie Beauvais visited the Branch in order to request that the grant of $200.00 allowed to her son to attend the Victoriaville College be transferred to the French Institute at Pointe aux Trembles, near Montreal, where Leslie attended for the past two years.

In reply I wish to say that upon her return from Ottawa Mrs. Beauvais called at this office and to my surprise produced a letter from the Sister Superior which she had written to her husband in the course of last summer offering a grant to their son Leslie for him to attend the Victoriaville College. This letter was praising Leslie very highly and it is believed that if this boy has so many qualities that he deserves a grant whether he attends Victoriaville or Pointe aux Trembles and I would therefore recommend that his grant be transferred to the latter institution. Leslie who is actually at Pointe aux Trembles, according to his mother, is in his 1st year of High School.

Relative to the giving of grants in future I would suggest that each case be scrutinized very carefully and that employees other than teachers alone be called upon to make suggestions and recommendations. In doing so cases like the above would be placed where they should attend at the beginning of the school year.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I want to thank you for your kind inquiry asking for information regarding our School and our courses in Electrical Engineering.

I want to impress upon you right from the start that the Canadian School of Electricity is the oldest and largest School of its kind in the Dominion of Canada specializing in teaching Electricity and Radio in a practical way.

The School offers the following courses:

1. Course in Practical Electrical Engineering, 6 to 8 months day-time or one year evening.
2. Course in Radio Engineering Electricity, radio, radio servicing, broadcasting, etc. (6 to 8 months day-time or one year evening)
3. Advanced course in radio, radio servicing, broadcasting, etc. (3 to 4 months day-time or 6 to 7 months evening)
4. Electrical or Mechanical Drafting (six months day-time or one year evening)
5. Special course in Practical Armature winding.
6. Special correspondence course in Electrical Engineering.
7. Special correspondence course in Radio Engineering.

DAY COURSE: The day course in Electrical Engineering is similar to that given in any college or university. The course can be completed in six to eight months. Besides Electrical Engineering, you will receive a very good training in Electrical Drafting and Electrical Mathematics.

Our condensed engineering course will give you a practical, thorough and intensive training in Electrical Engineering which prepares you for a Junior Engineering position, working under the direction of Electrical Engineers in the large Canadian Electric Power and Manufacturing concerns.

In Canada the Electrical Industry has doubled every five years since 1905, and double the number of trained men have been employed every five years in the great electrical industry. The great Electrical Power and Manufacturing Concerns are in need of trained electrical men at all times and the demand is always greater than the supply.

OUR GRADUATES SUCCEED: During the past ten years we have graduated over two thousand (2,000) students who are working for the largest power companies, electrical manufacturing concerns in Montreal and vicinity. Five of our graduates are Broadcast station operators with the La Presse Broadcast Station CKAC; five with the Marconi Station QFCF; two are with CRCK, Charlesbourg, Que; two with the Montreal Police Station UXH, one with CRCQ Ottawa; one in CHLT and one in CHLN Three Rivers. Twelve of graduates are employed by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation at Stat CBM and CBF Montreal and Vercheres, Que.

Cher Monsieur Brisebois,

Au début de l'année nous avions les jeunes indiens dont les noms suivent : Richard White, Matty Montour, Albert Stalk, Robert Jacobs, Gene Lahache, Paul Lahache, Norbert Rice, Peter Rice, Leslie Beauvais, Charles Taylor, Andrew Delisle, Oliver Montour, Ronald Le Clair, Kenneth Regis, Chester Albany, Vincent Budd, et Thomas Lazare.

Plusieurs ont quitté notre institution; certains avec raison, d'autres sans raison aucune.

Richard White et Matty Montour ont été priés de se retirer après certains désordres survenus au dortoir; ils ont été trouvés les principaux agents de ces désordres.

Robert Jacobs, jeune indien très intelligent, mais apathique n'a pu s'acclimater à la vie du pensionnat. Il voulait absolument réintégrer sa famille et agissait en conséquence; son travail scolaire a laissé beaucoup à désirer. Il quitta le collège avec le consentement des autorités et des parents après avoir déserté au début de janvier.

Norbert Rice n'est pas revenu en janvier. Il voulait poursuivre des études commerciales et nous n'avons que le cours classiques pendant les deux premières années du cours de High School.

Leslie Beauvais a été retiré par ses parents; l'enfant ne semblait pas s'acclimater.

Albert Stalk, Charles Taylor, Gene Lahache, Paul Lahache, Peter Rice ont quitté d'eux-mêmes et sans raison après le départ de White et Montour, leurs chefs de file.

Charles Taylor est intelligent et peut poursuivre des études. Peter Rice s'est toujours très bien comporté. Paul Lahache a quitté le Collège sans notre permission. Albert Stalk paraît incontenable.
Nous sommes satisfaits de ceux qui sont actuellement au Collège. Andrew Delisle est un très bon élève et il devrait réussir dans ses études. Oliver Montour, Ronald Le Clair, Kenneth Regis et Chester Albany nous fournissent une bonne somme de travail intellectuel. Thomas Lazare est très appliqué mais bien peu intelligent et il n'a pratiquement aucune chance de succès dans ses études. Vincent Budd ne nous donne guère satisfaction.

À la louange de vos jeunes indiens et de leurs dévouées maîtresses, il nous fait plaisir de louer leurs manières polies en notre présence. Cependant nous croyons qu'il manquent d'esprit de discipline et de travail.

J'espère que ces renseignements vous donneront satisfaction et je vous prie d'agréer, cher Monsieur Brisebois, l'expression de mes religieux sentiments.

Frère Fernand, s. c.,
Directeur
Caughnawaga, Que.,
March 1, 1948.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,

This also shows that greatest care should in future be taken by those recommending grants for their pupils.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

You will recall that some time last year we authorized the installation of two wash basins at the Caughnawaga teacher's residence. The basins were purchased but it has been impossible to secure plumbers to install them, due principally to the shortage of galvanized pipe. While at Caughnawaga, I interviewed two plumbers who are ready to undertake the job beginning on Monday or Tuesday of next week. They estimate the cost of installation, supplying all material that is at present lacking, for the sum of approximately $125.00. You know that there are 16 persons in this residence and this would be a very necessary installation. I would therefore strongly recommend that Mr. Brisebois be notified immediately if you should decide to have this installation carried on. This would permit the Agent to authorize this while the men are available.

I received your telegram re the investigation at the Victoriaville Boarding School. This school is approximately 125 miles from Caughnawaga. It is nearer Pierreville and I thought that I would visit this school on my next visit to Pierreville some time next month. I have, however, made an investigation of the reasons of this general exodus from the school. I am of the opinion that the parents have lacked interest in this project. This, I believe, is due to the fact that possibly we have not stressed the importance of this education to the parents. I would like to make the following recommendations. Children who apply for advanced education should be interviewed by an officer from Ottawa who should, together with the teacher and the agent, decide whether the applicant is suitable for this type of education. This step would obviate the difficulty the
teachers have of recommending. Should they recommend one child and feel that the neighbour should not have that type of education they have a difficult problem to face as regards the parents. We should also prepare forms which the parents should sign guaranteeing that they will give their complete support and see that their child will complete the course which he undertakes. Should he not be suited to take this course, then the parents will realize that it is not a question of the teacher not wishing but it is a question of our policy. Looking over the list of pupils and after investigating some of them, I find that one especially, Thomas Lazarre, has not the ability to assimilate the higher course and he should never have been recommended.

Should we adopt such a procedure, I am satisfied that we would get a better type of student in these schools and at the same time we would have a more stable scholar and, although the signature of the parents would have no legality, it would impress upon them the importance and the seriousness of the course. I will have the advantage of discussing the whole thing with you on my return some time next week. I will be leaving tonight for Sault Ste. Marie and expect to be back in Ottawa Thursday or Friday of next week.

Yours sincerely,

A. J. Doucet.

Dear Sir:

I am forced to have to appeal to your generosity regarding my daughter Helen Morris who is attending school in Montreal. I find that the burden is rather heavy and I can't carry on much longer without support from the Indian Department, as the Sisters of Saint Ann and the Indian Agent have refused my request for help.

Helen is still under sixteen years of age and therefore, must be kept in school. I wish you could make it possible to help pay her way to and from Montreal, which is $7.00 per month. I have forwarded the receipts for two months by Mr. Brisbois but so far have received no cheque for the amount of $14.00. Enclosed is the receipt for two other months.

I mean to keep her in school until she can get a trade and help to support herself, better than other girls. She is doing fine and it would not be fair if she failed in her aim on account of lack of funds. I am earning small wages and find it too big a sacrifice.

Trusting you will give this your careful consideration and that you will give me a satisfactory reply, that I may keep my two girls in school until they get a trade.

Awaiting an early reply.

Councillor:
Thos. H. Morris
Gaughnawaga, Que.,
April 28, 1943.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd of February last, enclosing the original of a communication received at the Branch from Thomas H. Morris of this Reserve in which he requested to be reimbursed for the travelling expenses of one of his daughter attending a Business College at Montreal, under a grant obtained from the Department.

In reply I wish to say that the two daughters of Morris obtained grants this year to attend the Business College.

One graduated in February and immediately obtained a position with the Bell Telephone Co., Montreal, as a typist.

The other graduated lately and is expecting a position in the near future.

As you are aware travelling expenses have been discontinued for pupils travelling to schools. It was considered that the parents, in mostly all cases, could very well afford to pay these expenses more particularly since they were getting grants for the tuition of their children.

In this case it is considered that Morris with the help of this daughter working at the Bell Telephone, could afford to pay the transportation of his daughter to and from Montreal. His letter is herewith returned.

ENCL.

(Frs. Brisebois)

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Before leaving for her holidays Miss Dely, Principal of the United Church Indian Day School had recommended five of her pupils for grants in order to allow them to further their studies. Their names are as follows, Sherril Diome, Rose Whitebean, Muriel Delisle, Peggy Oke and Lorraine Delisle. These girls have all completed their seventh grade successfully at the local U.C. School.

Arrangements have been made for them to attend the Lachine High School by Mr. Kennedy and the undersigned.

They will be admitted at this institution without any tuition fee.

As the parents of these girls are far from being well off and due to the fact that no tuition grant is being charged it is recommended that a sum of $5.00 per month per pupil be allowed to take care of their transportation from the Reserve to Lachine. This would be a reasonable price and arrangement could be made with a local car owner at the price above stated.

Dear Mr. Bristo:

I have completed arrangements with the Veterans' Administration here in New York and McGill University to continue my Law course in Canada.

Just now, I have been informed that the $152.00 deposit required by the Bar of Montreal before entrance into McGill will not be paid in accordance with the U.S. Bill under which I shall attend school. Consequently, this deposit appears to be the only obstacle in view for a fall entry.

It has been noted that, in recent years, the Officials in Ottawa have taken a keen interest in the education of the Indians. Perhaps, by pointing out that I was offered no assistance in the completion of my last three years of college, a letter to them requesting their aid with regard to the deposit of $152.00 might be given due consideration.

In view of the fact that the course commences on October 1st, I am extremely anxious to
have a letter written requesting the above. In this regard, I would greatly appreciate your assistance. But — you may deem it advisable for me to write personally, in which case, there would be no reluctance on my part to do so upon being informed of the name of the person to whom my letter should be addressed — one who would give my request every possible consideration.

The request is urgent and the need is sincere. I await your discretion in the matter.

Thanking you for your attention thus far,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,
Earl Taylor

September 2, 1948.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Supt. Indian Agency, Caughnawaga, P.Q.,

Caughnawaga Tuition.

I have for answer your letter of the 18th ultimo, with regard to the tuition fees for Therese Bright and Wesley Beauvais.

We have already brought to your attention in our letter of yesterday the fact that the Department is carefully reviewing all cases in which we have to pay boarding expenses for Indian children receiving higher education.

There are many children applying for tuition grants this year and each case has to be decided on its relative merits. In other words, we are quite prepared to pay boarding expenses of a child from Northern Manitoba or Saskatchewan who has to come down to the nearest city in order to attend high school.

There are very few cases in Ontario and Quebec where such boarding expenses would seem to be necessary. We pay no boarding expenses whatsoever at Six Nations and it is difficult to understand why we should continue to pay boarding expenses at Caughnawaga where high schools are available at both Lachine and Montreal.

Therefore, it will be necessary for you to explain why these two children can not attend school on a daily basis. Is there a special reason why these two children require institutional care?

This is a matter which I would like you to discuss with both the Missionaries and the Principals of your schools.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

You find herewith an application for grant on behalf of Bella Robertson an Indian of this Reserve which is made in order to enable her to attend the Chatelaine Business College at Lachine, Que.,.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Caughnawaga Tuition.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant dealing with the above subject and more particularly with the cases of Theresa Bright and Wesley Beauvais, who have applied to go to the French Institute at Pointe aux Trembles, Que.,

In reply I wish to inform that Theresa, who is the illegitimate daughter of an indian woman, has been attending this institution for the past two years and did very well. Her mother is not living on the Reserve, but in the United States. During the summer months she lives with relatives on this Reserve but these people would not keep her the year round. It is doubted if this girl would do as well with her studies if she were to travel daily to Montreal for her studies. The Pointe aux Trembles Institute is 25 miles from this Reserve, being located at the east end of the Island of Montreal.

Relative to Wesley Beauvais, you file will show that he attended the above Institution in 1947. However in 1948, he was sent to Victoriaville but came back shortly after the beginning of the academic year. For certain reasons he returned to Pointe aux Trembles and finished his year there. His father Joe L. Beauvais has been at the local Hospital for over three months and has requested that his son be permitted to return, under a Government grant, to the same place at least for this year.

[Fra. Brisebois]
Supt., Indian Agency.
September 22, 1948.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

We have your letter of the 16th instant with further reference to Theresa Bright and Wesley Beauvais.

From the information contained in your letter we feel that it would be preferable to send Theresa Bright to the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario. We are not prepared to pay a grant for her at Pointe aux Trembles. If the girl is willing to go to the Mohawk Institute, please let me know and further instructions will be given to you.

With reference to Wesley Beauvais, we understand that this boy is a Catholic and under Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act, we do not feel that we are at liberty to allow a grant for him to attend the institution mentioned in your letter.

If the boy could be placed in a Catholic institution, we would be prepared to consider giving him some assistance if you would recommend such action.

Bernard F. Ngary
Superintendent of Education.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant advising that the Branch will allow a tuition grant of $150.00 to assist Bernice Cross in taking a business course at Chatelaine Business College, Lachine, Que., and in which you also requested information about the Aviron Ltd., Trade and Art Course, (incidentally the address of this School is 384 West Sherbrooke St., Montreal.)

In reply I wish to inform that the last named institution was visited yesterday the 17th, and the Manager interviewed.

The trade courses given at Aviron Ltd., are practical ones, only. The pupils work all day under the constant supervision of their respective teachers. They have complete workshops with modern tools and equipment.

This school is approved by the Department of Veterans Affairs, has a considerable enrollment roll and both day and night courses are given. Stuart Mayo would attend day courses. His mother has already deposited the sum of $50.00 with the School which will represent her contribution for the tuition of her son. The courses to be followed are machinist and welding.

Please take this request into consideration.

(Fr. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.

Superintendent of Education.

September 23, 1948.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.,

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th in which a tuition grant of $90.00 was allowed to Vincent Budd to enable him to attend the Montreal Catholic High School and in which you also requested additional information in the case of Robert Jacobs.

In this connection I beg to inform that Robert failed last year and will have to repeat this year. However this is due to the fact that he underwent an operation for appendix and had a relapse and as a result of his operation was two months absent from school.

He is reported to be a good student and eager to succeed.

He is the eldest son of a family of six. His father died two years ago and the mother is quite anxious for him to get a good education.

Please reconsider his case.

(Fr. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
September 27, 1948.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd instant, it has been decided to allow a tuition grant of $36.00 for the period September 1st to December 31st, 1948, for Robert Jacobs.

You should submit a report about Christmas time regarding the work that he has done during the first four months of the academic year and we will then decide if we can renew the grant for the balance of the year 1948-49.

As you are aware, it is not our general practice to allow grants for those who have been unsuccessful and the additional opportunities which we are giving him as authorized in this letter, is simply due to the statement in your letter regarding his illness last year.

It should be distinctly understood by all parties concerned that a special exception has been made in the case of Jacobs and is not to form a precedent for the future.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

CANADA
One Kenneth Regis who was in receipt of a grant from the Department to attend the Victoriaville College, came back for the last instant, on vacation for a few days.

The boy did not return with the other pupils of that College but stayed in Caughnawaga for a week or until his father who was working in the United States, returned here, and took him back to Victoriaville.

After his father returned to the U.S., the boy came back to Caughnawaga.

Today the Sister Superior called at this office and applied for an increase in the grant of this boy and also applied for his transfer from Victoriaville to the Ottawa University.

Requested to state why she would recommend this increase in the grant and his transfer to Ottawa, the Sister stated that the boy did not like Victoriaville where, incidentally he attended last year, and would prefer to go to Ottawa.

This request is not recommended and if the boy has to be transferred he should attend a College at Montreal, where he could travel every day. A grant at the C.H.S. would amount to $10.00 per month instead of $25.00 paid to a residential School.

.....It seems....
It seems rather difficult to understand why such a request would be taken into consideration. Has it reached the point that a boy of 14 will leave an institution where his father wants him to attend, and come back off the Reserve and dictate where he wants to go (at the expense of the public?)

If this boy is not interested enough in his studies to remain at Victoriaville for the balance of this academic year it is extremely doubtfull that he would remain in another boarding School.

(Frs.Brisbois)
Supt., Indian Agency.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd of September, last, dealing with the cases of Theresa Bright and Wesley Beauvais of this Reserve who are attending the Pointe aux Trembles Institute. I wish to apologize for the delay in replying as your letter had been mislaid in our files.

Relative to the case of Theresa Bright, I wish to say that she has been attending the above institution for the past three years and is reported by the Principal to be doing very well. She is the illegitimate daughter of an Indian woman who is actually in the United States where she is working. Reverend Mr. Kennedy of the local U.C.Mission who is taking much interest in this girl would appreciate if she could finish the present academic term at Pointe aux Trembles. Theresa is interested in finishing her studies as she intends to become a school teacher. She is reported to have good dispositions for that career.

In connection with Wesley Beauvais, I have to point out that he attended Pointe aux Trembles in 1946 and went to Victoriaville for a few months in 1947, but was transferred to the former institution afterwards. Please refer to your letter of December 12, 1947, to our reply of the 16th of the same month and your authorization for him to attend Pte aux Trembles, dated December 22nd, 1947.
Referring to the religion of the parents of Leslie (not Wealey) the father is non-Catholic and the mother does not practice any religion. The father of this boy is a former pupil of the Pointe aux Trembles Institute and seems very anxious that his son remains there.

In view of the foregoing it would be appreciated if you could reconsider these two cases favourably.

[Fr. Brisebois]
Supt., Indian Agency.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to transmit you a request for grant from Mr. Dominique Giasson on behalf of his son Jean Marie for a course in refrigeration to be taken at the School "Aviron Limited" 384 Sherbrooke st., west, Montreal.

This boy has been attending the local schools and is actually in his eighth grade. He is 16 years old. The Rev. Principal states that although he is a fair pupil he does not seem to be too interested in his studies here, but that he shows aptitudes in manual work. She therefore wishes to recommend him for a grant to attend this trade school.

The father of the boy is willing to pay the sum of $50.00, plus his transportation and other incidental expenses, but would be unable to pay the full course.

As will be noted on the enclosed contract the grant requested is of $150.00. Please take this request into consideration.

For your information I have to advise that Stuart Mayo of this Reserve who recently completed a course at the above School (welding and mechanic) has found good employment with the training he acquired there.

(Fr. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
19th January, 1949.

Mr. Pw. Brisebois,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

We have your letter of the 8th instant with reference to tuition grant requested for Jean Marie Giasson.

We are not familiar with the school which this boy wishes to attend. We suggest that on the next occasion you visit Montreal, you arrange to have the Manual Training Instructor, Mr. Viau, contact you and he could visit Aviron Limitée.

No doubt Mr. Viau is aware of the academic standing of the boy and also what interest he has taken in the manual training course on the Caughnawaga Reserve. He will be in a position to decide if the course offered by the school mentioned above would be suitable for Giasson.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will refer to your letter of the 13th ultimo dealing with a request for grant on behalf of Jean Marie Giasson, an Indian of this Reserve in which you suggested that the Aviron Limited be visited by Mr. Vieu, Manual Training Instructor with a view of determining if the course offered would be suitable for this boy.

In reply I wish to inform that up to the present it had not been possible to visit this institution with Mr. Vieu, but at his last visit here, on the 2nd instant, Mr. Doucet advised that he had visited same the previous day. Mr. Doucet is now in a position to explain you in details the courses etc., given at the Aviron Limited.

As regards the academic standing of Giasson, Mr. Vieu advises that this boy has lost interest in his studies at the local Schools but that he is interested in manual training. He would therefore recommend the grant requested.

(Fr. Bribeois)
Supt., Indian Agency.

Mr. F. Brisebois,

You should report later regarding the success he achieves.

Bernard F. Neary

Dear Col. Neary,

During my recent visit to Ottawa I was speaking with Major Clark who asked me about our entrance pupils. Twelve of my grade seven pupils passed into grade eight which is first year high school in Quebec. As all of them are under sixteen they will be going to high school in Lachine.

I hadn't thought it necessary to write about them as there are no fees to pay, and it has been customary for our pupils to go to the Lachine High School as a matter of course. This year they may have to buy or rent text books, and there is always transportation to consider.

Sincerely yours,

Viola M. Daly.
July 15, 1949.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

Tuition - Caughnawaga U.C., Indian Children

We have received a letter from Miss Daly advising that twelve of her Grade 7 pupils have passed to Grade 8. She advises that those under sixteen will be going to highschool in Lachine. As they will be attending high school for the first time, it will be necessary for them to submit tuition application forms where help is needed.

It will not be necessary for the five girls now attending the Lachine High School to submit another application form. You can merely notify us at a later date if they have passed their Grade 9 examinations.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,

Re: Garfy Delisle

We have your letter of the 22nd ultimo requesting a tuition grant for the above boy.

As you are aware, this boy attended Ottawa University and last year attended the Catholic High School of Montreal. It is noted from your letter that he was unsuccessful in his year's work, and will have to repeat if he attends school during the academic year 1949-50.

It has not been our practice to pay a tuition grant for a repeater. We are reluctant to do so in this case, as it would be considered a precedent, and we would be required to give similar treatment to other repeaters in the future. However, there may be extenuating circumstances in this case. It is noted that he is only 16 years of age and is eligible for fourth year high school.

Before making a final decision, we would like to have your comments, taking into consideration the contents of this letter.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST

Like Mildred she also has $76.47 in savings in Ottawa under account #6-11. Mr. H. Gauthier, Acting Indian Agent, Christian Island, Ontario.

I have your letter of the 21st instant, submitting a request for tuition grants for Bella Elizabeth Maraden and Mildred Jane Monague.

It is noted from your letter that both of these girls are fifteen years of age and it will be necessary for them to secure boarding accommodation in Midland or London.

Accommodation where an Indian girl receives proper supervision out of school hours is very difficult to obtain and the Department feels that it would be in the best interest of the girls concerned if they entered the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario and attended the Brantford Collegiate.

I am certain that the Principal and the staff of the Mohawk Institute will give the girls every possible assistance and help in their academic work.

I trust that the girls will accept this recommendation and if so they should proceed to Brantford immediately as a copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Principal of that school.

In reply to your letter of August 28, 1946, file 103-6(WT)
Re: Tuition Grants for Della Marsden and Mildred Monague.

In the case of Della Marsden a home has been found in Midland
that has been highly recommended by the Principal of the Midland High
School and as the father and Grandparents wished to have her in a
school close enough for them to visit her and to have her visit them
on weekends, it was decided to have her attend the Midland School. Any
Grant the Department would see fit to help defray the costs of her
Board and Books would be appreciated. Your Concern about supervision
for the girls after school hours is also appreciated.

In the case of Mildred Monague, your recommendation that she
go to the Brantford Collegiate and stay at the Mohawk Institute was
acceptable but on the Eve of my departure with her and the seven
other children for the Mohawk Institute that you had approved I
received a wire from the School Principal advising me to hold the
children until he had communicated with you, as the school was nearly
filled. I am awaiting further instructions from you regarding same.

Mildred Monague has received a letter from her sister who is
attending High School in London, advising her that she has found a place
for her to board that she could have free in return for work after school
hours. I concur with your suggestion that the proper supervision might
not be enjoyed in this case. However in view of the fact that she is
desirous of and anxious to attend High School, I would appreciate an
early reply in her case so that I could advise her on the course that
would be of the best interests to all concerned.

I have still had no word about teachers for the U.C.School here
on the Island. The R.C.School opened on Sept. 4.

Yours truly,

Henry Gauthier
Acting Indian Agent.

My dear Mr. Gauthier:

She has in the past been paying her own way by working for the people with whom she resides in her after hours, and as this arrangement will be carried on next term again failing her receiving a Tuition grant, I feel that were she receiving the customary $20.00 per month grant, she would be in a better position to give more time to her studies and consequently be assured of a better chance of obtaining her matriculation. The $20.00 grant would enable her while remaining in the same home allow her more time to herself, and I would recommend that this grant be made available. Mr. Miller the principal has been quite co-operative and would I am sure keep us advised as to her progress.

The grant could either be made payable through this office for remittance to her or directly. Her London address would be Miss Vena Monague, 270 Huron Street, London Ontario.

Awaiting your comments, I remain,

Henry Leuthier,

Philip Phelan,

I wish to draw your attention to the fuel requirement for the Caradoc Indian Continuation School and Mr. Joblin's apartment; also janitor for the school. You will appreciate the fact that he has not yet officially been advised of Mr. Joblin's appointment, neither do I know what arrangements were made with him. He advises that house, fuel and light were mentioned. I have therefore authorized, until definite instructions are received, two tons of coal for his apartment and given him a full load of coke from our Day school supplies for the furnace, which must be replaced.

In discussing the requirements with Mr. Joblin and inspecting the basement I noticed a heavy supply of blower coal. I asked him whether it could not be used. He said the furnace was broken but that he had ordered the part and if it arrived in time, the blower coal could be used. I am now awaiting news of the part he mentioned. In the meantime, every endeavour is being made to keep the classrooms and apartment warm and comfortable.

With regard to the janitor, we are going to have some difficulty and until we can determine the duties involved and the salary offered there will be some inconveniences.

I would also draw your attention to paper towels and toilet tissue. These articles are necessary in the school and I have again depleted primary school supply stocks to supply the Continuation School and I am ordering a supply of both articles accordingly. I trust that my action in this matter is in order without having first submitted the request for your consideration.

It will interest you to learn that the school, to date, is progressing favourably and everything possible is being done for the comfort of the pupils and teachers. The new school, owing to joists for the upper structure not being available, is at a standstill. I have submitted, through the surveyor, the results obtained with the building which are traced and attributed directly to officials of the engineering and Surveying Branch, of the Department of Mines & Resources.

Mr. Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent,
Muncey, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Down,

In making a guess at the amount of coal likely to be needed for the furnace this year, it is quite possible that I was too low in my estimate. At least that is the opinion of Chanocoy and Mr. Johnston, both of whom know the situation better than I do. I had understood that the men estimated the coal used last year at 35 tons, but Chanocoy tells me now that this was only the one bin which they moved. Since there must have been another ten tons in the other bin, and since there should be added around fifteen tons for the two apartments, it seems that my guess should have been nearer 50 tons than 35.

I leave it to your judgment, if you have not already sent in the former amount, whether it would be wise to requisition for the larger amount, than to run the risk of having to send in another requisition later. The whole matter is so much guesswork, of course, which is not too satisfactory, but it would seem better to err with too large an amount than too little.

Truly Yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I would advise that Mary Sutherland, daughter of No. 521, Charles Sutherland, Chippewas of Thames Band of Indians, passed the Entrance examination in June of this year. The father of this girl as well as the girl herself wishes that she continue her studies in High School work.

Gentlemen:

We have in attendance this year at the Mount Brydges Continuation School Stanley Dottator of the Huncay Indian Reserve. When we billed the County of Middlesex for the cost of this pupil's education, they told us that they were not responsible and suggested that the Department of Indian Affairs should pay the bill.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, no authority has been given by this Department for Stanley Doxtator to attend the Mount Brydges Continuation School. Under these circumstances I regret that no payment can be made for his tuition fees. We have a small amount in our appropriation each year for tuition fees for deserving Indians but authority for a grant must first be obtained. No such request was received for Doxtator and, as the amount available has been completely assigned, no further consideration can be given to the matter at the present time.

In regard to Harold Dodson, I may say that his father was the teacher of the senior classroom at the Mount Elgin Residential School for several years and was paid by the school management. Mr. Dodson is not an Indian and consequently this Department is not responsible for the education of his children.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Does your Dept. make grants toward the education of Indian young people beyond the grade school? I have been informed that you do and I should like to call to your attention two cases which are particularly worthy of assistance.

Gerald Fisher completed his grade school work at Mt. Elgin, and began Technical School in London last fall, supporting himself (at least in part) with money he had saved when working in the tobacco harvest. He has been unable to return to school since Christmas, and last week we buried his grandmother who was his guardian. The grandmother's husband is willing to help but has no binding obligation in the case. The boy is a Chippewa and the foster grandfather is Oneida.

The other case is that of a son of a veteran of the last war. The father is in receipt of a pension and due to disability is unable to work steadily. He has been in the Sanatorium once or twice. The boy began school last fall but suffered an accident and after recovery the family finances would not permit his return. The father has intended sending a request to your Dept. for help but had decided that the boy would do well now to wait till next fall before going on.

I would be very pleased to learn your attitude toward these cases, and will secure any other information you may require.

I am the United Church minister on the Reserve.

Sincerely yours,

E. S. Curriead.
Ottawa, March 8, 1945.

Dear Mr. Linstead:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to grants to enable two Indian pupils to obtain higher education.

We are prepared to favourably consider making tuition grants to deserving Indian pupils, provided they have the necessary background. It is not usual to provide the full cost, as we feel that the parents or others interested in the boys should make a contribution. However, there may be special cases in which payment of the full cost may be justified.

There is one stipulation, which I think you will agree is very necessary. That is, that any pupil desiring a tuition grant should apply either in July or early in August to the Indian Agent, who in turn will supply us with full information on the form prepared for that purpose, and a copy of which I enclose. You will realize that it would be impossible for us to control expenditure unless our authority was obtained before the academic year actually started.

I note that Gerald Fisher has been attending the Technical School in London, using money which he himself earned. It is regretted that he did not bring his request to our attention earlier, because I note from your letter that he has been absent from the school since Christmas, although you do not state the reason for this. Do you feel it advisable for him to return now, after losing over two months of the present

Mr. E. S. Linstead,
Muncy, Ont.
academic year? I wish you would discuss his case with the Indian Agent and possibly you could obtain some information from the Principal of the Technical School at London, indicating whether he thinks the boy could benefit by returning to school now, or would it be preferable for him to wait until the academic year 1945-46?

I note also the other case to which you refer, but you do not state the boy's name. However, his case could also be discussed with Mr. Down, but it is noted that no assistance would be necessary until the coming academic year.

You will note from the form enclosed that a medical examination is required. The Department feels that before we make any tuition grant we should have some assurance that the applicant is physically fit to take advantage of the advanced education that might be given to him.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Indian Agent Down who, I am certain, will give sympathetic consideration to the two cases mentioned in your letter and will write us following his interview with you.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Encl.
Reference is made to your letter of September 17th, with regard to tuition grants for Indian pupils wishing to continue higher education.

In this connection, some months ago, I wrote Miss Torrance, Sec., Treas., Delaware Continuation School, but she has not yet answered my letter. However, the Rev. Mr. Allison, a recently appointed member of the Village of Delaware School Board, recently called at my office in connection with Indian pupils wishing to continue their educations. I explained to him the procedure for such and pointed out that authority for upper school education, where it involves the Department of Indian Affairs, must come from Ottawa and that the child concerned should obtain a fair standing in its primary school examinations and the teachers report show at least some justification. I also pointed out that officials in Ottawa were quite generous in considering deserving cases.

In the cases mentioned by Miss Torrance, they are all, I understand, doing house work in the Village of Delaware and attending the small Continuation School, and the people they are with, being tax payers, assume that it is their right to send the girls to school without interference from Miss. Torrance, or the Rev. Mr. Allison. However, one started last year and two this year; but not one has, either through their teacher or this office made application for assistance. Since your letter was received, parents have been advised of the procedure necessary, which, by the way, they are well

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Schools and Education:

As time goes on the average Indian Day School presents a problem and I am convinced that a change in the management and general set up of Indian education is upon us. Accessibility, teacher accommodation, overcrowding, insecurity and low salaries are contributing factors in what might be termed "The March of Education." If consolidated schools is not the answer, serious thought must be given to a building program of adequate class-room accommodation and opportunities for higher education.

The march of time is away from the one class-room little red school house and the time is here for our Indians to demand the same rights and facilities as their white brothers. If we are to help our Indian people and prepare them for the years that lie ahead, serious thought must be given to education and proper school facilities.

The Back Settlement Indian School, as you are aware, has, for the past three and one-half years been conducted in the basement of the Anglican Church. This was never a popular arrangement, especially with the church's congregation and I understand that the local management recently petitioned Church Officials to have the government assume its own responsibility.

From my regular school visits I found school management, under varying circumstances, favourable. Academically, I think our Indian children compare favourably with other sections. The percentage of passes at summer Entrance examinations was very satisfactory and several pupils are continuing their education in Continuation Schools and Collegiates under white supervision.

Geo. W. Down,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

There has been a misunderstanding in the Delaware Continuation School as a result of the entrance of two pupils in September, 1944.

The school board felt that the fees would be paid by the County - the usual procedure when an outside pupil is admitted. However, when the secretary-treasurer of the Board sent in the accounts at the beginning of the year 1945 (the usual time) to the county clerk where they are audited by high school auditors, the school board was told that the county had nothing whatever to do with these pupils - that they would have to get their money from the Department of Indian Affairs.

Now the Department of Indian Affairs say that they will not be responsible since they were not consulted about the children being sent to the continuation school. I feel that the school board should be reimbursed for this as it is only a technicality. The school board has always taken pupils from any outside district when they sought admission.

Will you be kind enough to look into this and see if it is not possible to reimburse the school for this. The secretary-treasurer of the board is Miss Agnes Torrance, Delaware, Ontario. I will certainly appreciate your personal attention to this matter.

Yours very truly,

Robert McCubbin.

FOREWORD

The Annual Announcement of the H. B. Beal Technical and Commercial High School is issued to assist parents in making a wise selection of a secondary school, with the capabilities and preferences of the individual student in view. Parents are advised to read it carefully. Further inquiry with reference to the school courses is invited. Personal interviews will be welcomed.

When making the selection of a Secondary School, parents will do well to consider the opportunities for employment that present themselves to city youth when leaving school. A survey of a typical Ontario city in normal times shows that the numbers entering the gainful occupations are divided approximately as follows: Commerce 25%; Industries 70%; Professions 5%. In other words, for every opportunity in the professions there are four in commerce and five in industry. The Technical and Commercial High School gives direct preparation for more than 95% of these occupations. What occupation will your son or daughter follow? Will he or she be prepared for it?

The H. B. Beal Technical and Commercial High School is classified as a Vocational School by the Provincial Department of Education. Courses in Vocational Schools are designed primarily for students who do not intend to go to a University, but whose formal education will end at a Secondary School level. These courses provide a comprehensive, cultural, secondary school education, combined with an intensive, vocational training for industrial, commercial, business, institutional or homemaking occupations. A student who graduates from one of the four-year courses in a Vocational School receives from the Department of Education, a Secondary School Graduation Diploma. This same diploma is granted to students who graduate from Grade XII of High Schools and Colleges of Technology. A graduate, from any Secondary School, may enter Grade XIII and qualify for an Honour Secondary School Graduation Diploma. Consequently, a student who takes a Vocational Course and later decides to enter a University, is eligible for Engineering, Household Science, Commerce, Physiotherapy and Occupational therapy courses in University, provided the student has the necessary standing in the Upper School Subjects for the course of his or her choice.

Nurses' Courses

Any Secondary School Graduation Diploma is now the minimum requirement for admission to Nurses' Training Schools. Graduates from this school are accepted into nurses' training courses of all Ontario hospitals.

Apprenticeship Allowance

By special legislation of the Department of Labour of the Province, a graduate of a Vocational School is allowed one or two years off the apprenticeship period required in various trades under the control of the apprenticeship commission.

Examination Reports

The progress of students is ascertained by regular periodic tests combined with teachers' reports of students' work. The results are forwarded to parents and guardians three times a year, viz., in December, March, and June. Parents should examine these reports carefully. The Principal and Headmasters welcome conferences with parents, guardians and students with reference to any matters arising from the content of these reports or the students' progress at any time.

Health Service

The Health Department includes a complete dental office, a consulting office for the school doctor and nurse, a hospital and first aid room and a waiting room. A full-time nurse, a full-time dentist and assistant are on duty in the school and regular calls are made by the Board of Education doctors. This provides a health service second to none in the Province.

Fees

There are no fees charged for students who are residents of London. Fees for the residents of counties having an agreement with the London Board of Education are paid by the counties in accordance with the agreement. Students from other municipalities that do not have agreements with the London Board may be admitted by paying a fee of $12.00 a month.
SCHOOL ACTIVITIES

These provide for the all-round development of the students mentally, socially and physically.

Auditorium and Gymnasium

THE AUDITORIUM of the school is one of the most modern in the Province and has seating accommodation for over 1500 people. It is equipped with an excellent public address system which, by being extended to the gymnasium makes it possible for an assembly of three thousand to hear a speaker or programme. Modern radio and sound motion picture equipment permit students to hear outstanding radio broadcasts and have the benefits of the latest developments in visual education. The school assembles daily in the auditorium with the school orchestra in charge of the music.

This school has a gymnasium for boys and one for girls each equipped with up-to-date apparatus for physical and health education, and supplied with hot and cold showers, and dressing rooms. The advantages of a separate gymnasium specially equipped for girls will be appreciated by discriminating parents.

The Health and Physical Education Course in the school includes general gymnastics, work physiology, culture, health lectures, and out-of-door athletics under the direction of Physical Training Specialists, and the school doctors and nurses. The Cecil Carrother's Athletic Field provides for football, softball, and other outdoor sports.

Students' Organizations

Ample opportunity for the development of the students in public speaking, oratory, debating, athletics, music and conduct of affairs, is afforded through the numerous students' organizations. These include well-organized literary and athletic associations, a school orchestra, a school band, a glee club, etc.

Library

The school library is in charge of a qualified librarian. The students are given instruction in the selection and the use of books, as part of their regular school courses. Students are taught to use the school circulating library, and also the facilities of the public libraries.

Vocational Guidance

One of the important functions of the school is to assist pupils in selecting vocations for which their natural aptitudes fit them, and in which, by preparation, they should be successful. The Practical Departments of the school represent typical industrial occupations, and the instructors are master mechanics, with many years' experience, who are well acquainted with the requirements of industrial life. Each student participates in varied Vocational work during the first year, and is thus enabled, with the advice of the instructors, to make an intelligent choice of a vocation. He may then major, and finally specialize in the department selected.

Trained and experienced Counsellors devote certain periods daily to the task of interviewing students in connection with their educational or vocational problems. In these interviews the Counsellors assist the students in adjusting themselves to the regular work of the school and to activities outside the classroom. Every effort is made to make the students feel that, while they have the privilege of attending a large, well-organized, and well equipped school, their individual needs are carefully considered and met.

In the task of assisting students or parents in making suitable educational and vocational choices, the school has the services of the Director of Vocational Guidance, Mr. J. P. S. Nethercott. He will arrange personal interviews with students or parents, either in the school or in his office at the Board of Education where he can be reached by calling Metcalf 7000.

Placement Department

The school has a well-organized Placement Department comprised of the Senior Counsellors and the heads of the practical departments of the school. Many students have profited from carefully selected and supervised "Part-time" jobs which, in some cases, have made it possible for them to continue their education. Suitable positions for graduates have been found through this department and with the assistance of the Director of Vocational Guidance who co-operates with Selective Service.

The aim of the Placement Department is to find the very best position for which the graduate, by aptitude and training, is fitted. Close contact with local firms is maintained to keep in touch with their requirements and to secure positions which will provide suitable graduates for all positions. In this way, the school has established a reputation for providing suitable trained help for all industries whether in office or shop. Former students know that this Placement Service is always available to them, and this arrangement has proven to be extremely valuable to all concerned.

These courses provide an intensive vocational training for the occupations named and are open to anyone, who, in the opinion of the principal, is capable of taking the work. (See Page 16.)

"The School That Aids Its Students In Securing Suitable Employment"
General Technical High School Course For Boys

Open to Students with High School Entrance, or equivalent standing

THE TECHNICAL HIGH SCHOOL Course is a four-year Secondary School course to provide boys with a thorough secondary school education, and at the same time prepare them for skilled positions in the industries. The course provides a broad, cultural High School education together with a special vocational training for boys.

Half the boy's time is spent in academic studies, taught by qualified High School teachers and directly correlated with the practical work of the school. Practical shop work in Machine Shop, Electricity, Woodworking, Auto-Mechanics, Sheet Metal Work, Printing, Applied Science, Welding, Draughting, Art and Music occupies the other half of the boy's school time.

The first year of the course has a general character, including the essentials of a good general high school education, with a sufficient variety of practical work to afford an opportunity for making an intelligent choice of a vocation for which the boy's aptitudes fit him. The shop instructors of the school have had years of practical trade experience and teacher training, and their advice is available to parents and students who are making a selection of the course in which the student is to major during his second and succeeding years.

During the remainder of this course a student continues with less intense academic studies, but devotes an increasing amount of time to a chosen major shop subject. A Secondary School Graduation Diploma, designating the shop department in which the student took the major part of his practical work, issued by the Department of Education, is granted to those who successfully complete the course.

Subjects of General Technical High School Courses for Boys

Health and Physical Education, English (Literature, Composition, Spelling), Social Studies (History, Civics, Geography, Economics), French (Optional), General Science, Chemistry, Physics, Electrical Work, Welding, Mathematics (Arithmetic, Shop Calculations, Trigonometry, Practical Geometry, Algebra), Mechanical Draughting, Architectural Draughting, Woodworking, Machine Shop Practice, Building Construction, Printing, Motor Mechanics, Welding, Art, and Music.

Home Economics Course For Girls

Open to Students with High School Entrance or Equivalent Standing

THE Economics Course for girls is a four-year cultural course especially suited to the needs of girls. Approximately half the student's time is spent in academic subjects, taught by qualified High School teachers and directly correlated with the practical work of the school.

In addition to providing a thorough academic cultural education, the Home Economics Course for girls prepares them for home-making activities and such occupations as Nursing, Dietetics, Institutional Management, Dressmaking and Salesmanship. A Secondary School Graduation Diploma issued by the Department of Education, is granted those who successfully complete the course.

Note: A ruling of the Department of Health states that a Secondary School Graduation Diploma from any four-year Secondary School course constitutes the educational prerequisite for admission to a course, leading to a Registered Nurse's Certificate. Students from the H. B. Beal Technical and Commercial High School are now accepted into Nurses' Courses in all London Hospitals.

Subjects of the Home Economics Course for Girls

Health and Physical Education, English (Literature, Composition, Spelling, Grammar), Penmanship, Business Practice, Music, Social Studies (History, Civics, Geography), French (optional), Mathematics (Arithmetic, Algebra, Practical Geometry), Chemistry, Physics, Typewriting, Household Science including Cookery, Dietetics, Home Nursing, Hygiene, Physiology, Household Arts including Dressmaking, Textiles, Choice, Care and Cost of Clothing, Costume Design, Art, and First Aid.
University Entrance

UNDER the new courses of study introduced in the province, all students of Vocational schools who satisfactorily complete any one of the four-year courses, are entitled to a Secondary School Graduation Diploma. The Universities of the province accept this diploma, along with standing in certain specified subjects of Upper School, as the required entrance to University courses. As a result, any student of the school who has completed the twelfth grade of any Commercial high school course may proceed to the thirteenth grade with his or her Upper School standing in the subjects necessary for admission to the Faculty of Applied Science, or the Faculty of Household Science, or to courses in Commerce, Nursing, Occupational Therapy, Physiotherapy and Social Science in Ontario Universities.

Since Upper School standing in French is required for practically all of the above Courses, a student who intends to proceed to University should take French commencing in the second year of his Vocational School Course. To permit a student to do this, French may be taken as an additional optional subject in any course in the school.

The Faculty of Applied Science and Engineering includes the following courses: Civil Engineering, Mining Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Metallurgical Engineering and Architecture.

The work in drafting, applied science, mathematics and shop work provided in Technical High Schools is often selected and arranged to provide a direct preparation for students entering the above courses in the University. This work is more adapted to secondary school methods of instruction than to University methods. It is a decided advantage to a student to enter the Engineering Course of a University with the basic training in the mechanical draughting and practical shop subjects acquired in a Technical School. The work in Household Arts and Household Science leads up to, without duplicating, the University Courses.

The value of the preparation provided in the Technical High School is demonstrated in the high standing obtained by its graduates in the University Courses of Engineering and Applied Science, Household Arts and Household Science.

Students who do not enter the University on completing the above course provided in Technical High Schools, have received valuable vocational training which enables them to qualify for various profitable occupations in the business and industrial world.

"The School That Aids Its Students In Securing Suitable Employment"

General Commercial High School Course

Open to Students with High School Entrance or equivalent standing

THE General Commercial High School Course is a four-year course which is designed to provide a good academic secondary school education together with a thorough training for office work and mercantile positions. Parents may be sure that their sons and daughters will receive an excellent and practical training in stenography, typewriting, bookkeeping, penmanship, and other essential Commercial subjects. The facilities of the Commercial Departments are not excelled by any other Commercial School or Business College in the province. Students are trained to meet the actual needs of business.

In Grade IX the student has all the regular high school subjects except that in place of French he gets typewriting, and penmanship. In Grade X shorthand, record-keeping and bookkeeping may be added to French or be taken as an extra subject. Thus in the first two years, the student receives good academic education and also begins his business training by taking such subjects as commercial arithmetic, typewriting, business practice, record-keeping, and bookkeeping. In Grade XI and XII the work becomes more specialized, the student taking either the clerical or the secretarial course.

(1) Clerical Course - In this course specialized training in Grade XI and XII is given in record-keeping, office practice, business machines, salesmanship, bookkeeping, typewriting, etc. The courses are planned for students who have found out in their first two years that they have an aptitude and liking for commercial arithmetic, bookkeeping and similar subjects, and who are looking forward to taking positions as bookkeepers, machine operators, clerk-typists, junior accountants, etc.

(2) Secretarial Course - In Grades XI and XII specialized work is given to prepare students for secretarial positions. An excellent and practical training is provided in shorthand, typewriting, office practice, etc.

In both of the above courses, academic subjects are obligatory but increased time is allotted to the commercial subjects, so that the student becomes thoroughly trained in the use of the most modern office equipment and appliances such as adding machines, calculators, duplicating machines and the dictaphone.

At the end of four years, i.e., Grade XII, the student is granted a Secondary School Graduation Diploma in Commercial

"The School That Aids Its Students In Securing Suitable Employment"
General Commercial High School Course (Continued)

subjects issued by the Department of Education. This will be a passport to stenographic and clerical positions.

Since this General Commercial High School Course provides for the commercial subjects to be spread over four years, students are able to obtain a most extensive and thorough training for business positions. Students with High School Entrance standing are therefore advised to enter the General Commercial Course immediately on leaving Public School rather than to take one, two, or three years in the General Collegiate or Technical High School Courses, and then taking an intensive commercial course of one or two years.

Subjects of the General Commercial High School Course

English (Literature, Composition, Spelling, Business Correspondence), Social Studies (History, Geography, Economics, Salesmanship), Music, Guidance, General Science, Arithmetic, Business Practice, Rapid Calculation, Record Keeping, Bookkeeping, Home Economics or Shop Work, Typewriting, Shorthand, Penmanship, Business Machines, Office Practice, Business Law, and Health Education.

Special One-Year Business Course

Open to students with at least Three Years' Technical, Collegiate, or Academic High School standing

THIS course is made up entirely of vocational commercial subjects, and affords students, who have completed three or more years in any Secondary School, the opportunity of preparing for mercantile and business positions in the shortest time possible. On the satisfactory completion of this one-year course, a Secondary School Graduation Diploma will be granted. Students may choose either the secretarial or the clerical option (see preceding page for a general description of these courses).

Subjects of the Special One-Year Commercial Course

Spelling, Correspondence, Stenography, Typewriting, Rapid Calculation, Bookkeeping, Business Machines, Economics, Salesmanship, Business Law, Penmanship, Physical Education, and Defence Training.

Art Course For Boys And Girls

Open to students with High School Entrance or equivalent standing

THE ART COURSE is a four year course that meets the requirements of the curriculum designed and recommended by the Department of Education in Toronto. At the end of this course, students are granted a Secondary School Graduation Diploma in Art.

During the first year, the student enrolls in any of the courses offered in the school such as the General Technical School course for boys or the Home Economics course for girls. In the second and succeeding years, approximately half the student's time is allotted to Art, Crafts and other allied subjects, and the other half to the essential subjects of a High School Academic education.

In this course students obtain a thorough High School Academic training and in addition a comprehensive training in Art and related subjects. Graduates of this course are qualified for employment that entails actual Art work such as drawings for newspaper and magazine reproduction. They also go to other types of employment which require artistic knowledge and skills, such as interior decorating, crafts, costume design, sign writing, display and window dressing.

Subjects of the Art Course for Boys and Girls

Health and Physical Education, English (Literature, Composition, Spelling, Grammar), Music, Social Studies (History, Civics, Government), French (Optional), Mathematics (Arithmetic, Algebra, Practical Geometry), Chemistry, Physics, Art, Architectural Draughting, Cookery, Dress-making, Textiles, Choice, Cost and Care of Clothing, Costume Design for girls and Practical Shop Work for boys.

Eighth Grade Course For Boys

Open to Students with Eighth Grade Standing

THE EIGHTH GRADE COURSE is especially suited to the needs of boys who have failed in the High School Entrance Examinations, and for those who have passed into Grade Eight and whose school time is limited. The course provides the elements of a good general education, combined with practical training. This combination of shop work and academic studies appeals to boys of the 'teen age. In this course, half the student's time is

Boys who have not been successful in passing the High School Entrance Examination will find this course especially interesting. THE EIGHTH GRADE COURSE FOR GIRLS is a specially organized school course suited to the educational needs of older girls. The essentials of the work of Grade VIII are covered before the student proceeds with studies of High School grade; the work is presented from a new standpoint and should have greater attractiveness for the student who has failed on the High School Entrance Examination, than the repetition of Grade VIII work in the school previously attended. Ray Ninham - Tuition

In London recently I discussed this boy's progress and possibilities with the Principal, and also with the Art teacher. They think he can develop into a fair commercial artist. This represents a change from his earlier notion to train as a mechanic.

The principal explained that they had provided him with a scholarship of $50 from a fund for helping students.

Apr. 5, 1948.

Re: Your File 103-7 (e.1)

I have your correspondence with regard to Ray Ninham who is attending the Beal Technical Institute in London, Ontario. Major Clark, during his recent visit, also mentioned this boy and apparently he had received some story of Ray's parentage and Indian status; therefore I propose first to straighten out his racial origin.

He is the son of Dorothy Ninham, a daughter of Nancy Ninham. Nancy Ninham, his grandmother, an Oneida Indian in full membership of the Oneida Band, is still living and residing on the Oneida Indian Reserve. His mother, Dorothy Ninham, is still living and lives in the area of Tillsonburg, Ontario. His father is unknown but supposed to have been an Oneida Indian, therefore Ray's racial origin is Indian and he is a member of the Oneidas of the Thames Band. I trust this will clear up the question of racial origin and his present status.

With regard to his registration as a pupil of the Beal Institute the story is as follows. On his graduation from the Mr. Elgin Residential School he went to London to work and, I understand, has attended night school. The following year, without the knowledge of this Office, he registered as a pupil at the Beal expecting to meet his own financial obligations. As the year went on he found the load a little too heavy and applied to me for whatever assistance we could give. This was referred to your Office and $2.62 was provided. The following year Ray wrote expressing his wish to continue with his studies and also received a letter from his principal, Mr. McWilliams, suggesting that the boy be given some assistance to carry on with his education. This was referred to your Office and in addition to a few odd incidental expenses $100.00, at my suggestion, was provided to assist Ray. At no time was there any correspondence or conversation intimating that the Department would assume full financial responsibility for books, board or tuition fees. On checking Ray's file I find that to date he has received financial assistance during the current term year for books and other necessities in the amount of $51.25.

I trust this information will answer your questions. However, Ray is an exceptional boy and is making use of the
opportunity offered. I would therefore recommend that the payment of this account be favourably considered. I would also suggest that, before Ray enrolls for another year, he, also his principal, be advised that the amount of financial responsibility expected from the Department be definitely assured.

Yours truly,

Geo. W. Down,

Re: Your File 103-7
Letter dated Apr. 12/48

The above-mentioned letter regarding Ray Ninham was drawn to my attention when the student was in the Office last Saturday requesting some assistance toward his expenses whilst in attendance at the Beal Technical School.

Yesterday I visited the School and interviewed Mr. Curry, the Assistant Headmaster, and Mr. Harris, Assistant Specialist, who has the youth in his class for all but three subjects.

Both were very enthusiastic about the pupil. Mr. Harris remarked "That he was a credit to his race and to Canada". He is rated among the best six prospects in the whole school.

Mr. Harris, his art teacher, said he could place Ninham in employment at any time, but he is in a class with three other outstanding pupils who ought to complete Grade 12 and they would have no trouble in placing him in a very good position, much better than the average Commercial Art job in the stores.

There is no sign of any inferiority complex now. Ninham is taking part in school activities and this year
is playing in the football team. He has been doing odd jobs around the school; last year he spent a little too much time working and this affected his studies to a certain extent. He had to do this to pay for his room and board.

Both gentlemen said he was worth any assistance that can be given to him. They have entered him for several scholarships and recommended him for a $50.00 Bursary.

I think a grant in this case would be a worthwhile investment and would recommend that a grant of $150.00 be made to purchase books etc., and to assist with clothing and living expenses.

His 1947-48 Report is attached. Please return this.

Yours truly,

F. Matters,
REG. SUPERVISOR.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

As requested in your letter dated October 17th, we submit the following report.

The required course may be secured at the Technical School, London, Ontario or at either Westervelt or Wells Business Schools, both of London. I would recommend the Technical School because I believe their course is at least as good as that given at the other schools and the cost is less. The Business Schools charge $25.00 per month and the Technical School charges a per diem basis which would be approximately $15.00 to $18.00 per month. Mr. McWilliams, principal of the Technical School, is of the opinion that with the training Harrietta has had, she should complete the course by May or June of 1950.

Besides tuition dues there would be the cost of books - approximately $25.00 and board at perhaps $9.00 or $10.00 per week. On this basis I would estimate the total cost of the course at $500.00.

With a little time for scouting it might be possible to place
this girl in a home where she could work part time and thus pay part of the cost of board. She may also be able to buy her own books. Her father is unable to help her.

An immediate reply is necessary if Harrietta is to be permitted to commence the course by November 1, 1949.

Yours truly,

Fred Hall,
