Re: Harrietta Ann Dockstader
Your File 130-12 (7)

We are in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant with further reference to the above mentioned girl.

The expenditure required is somewhat heavier than we expected. However, it has been decided to allow her an amount not exceeding $500.00. She should definitely understand that this is the total amount that we are prepared to grant.

It is hoped that she will be able to complete the course by the date mentioned in your letter. It is also hoped that you will be able to place her with a reputable family, who will supervise her leisure time. I also suggest that you should have the Principal of the Technical School send you monthly reports regarding her progress, and if her work is not satisfactory, you should let us know.

Re: Ray Ninham
Departmental File 42007-3 (E1)

Recently we received a telephone call from Ray Ninham concerning help from the Department. I was in London on October 20th and called at the school. I talked with both Ray and Mr. Mc Williams, the principal of the school.

Ray is in great need of financial assistance if he is to continue his studies and he is very anxious to do so. Mr. Mc Williams is favourably impressed with Ray's work this year and with his attitude toward his work. His marks are much above his work of a year ago.

The Departmental letter received by us under file 42007-3 (E1) dated September 12, 1949 mentioned only assistance so far as tuition fees were concerned. We are anxious to know whether any further assistance can be given to Ray.

Date: June 10th, 1949
Memorandum

Recently our electrical engineer made an electrical inspection of three schools, a Council Hall and Indian Agent's Residence and out-buildings at the above.

It was necessary to measure up the buildings on the job as architectural plans of these buildings were not available in this office. Plans and specifications have been prepared for the required electrical work and blueprints of our drawings and copies of our specifications will be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch in the near future. It is recommended that they be sent to the Indian Agent and that tenders be invited from electrical contractors in the vicinity, and that Indian Affairs let a contract for the execution of the work as soon as possible. The Ontario Hydro Electric Power Commission officials at Owen Sound indicated to our officer that the primary line construction should be completed in the near future and that minimum rates would be charged upon completion of their line.

While at Wiarton our engineer was contacted by Mr. W. H. Taylor of the Gillies Telephone System located at Lion's Head, a private company providing telephone service to subscribers at the Indian Reserve, including among others, the schools and the Indian Agent's office. The present type of telephone service is provided by stringing the ground wire system too low when the Hydro transmission line is energized, so inoperative due to inductive interference. Mr. Taylor pointed out that the Company's net annual returns from this line amounts to $140.00 per year, and that he estimates the conversion of approximately 11 miles of telephone line to a two wire system will amount to approximately $1,6000.00, an expenditure which is prohibitive to the Company in view of revenue derived therefrom.

This matter is brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch so that steps may be taken to arrive at an agreement with the Telephone Company for the conversion of the system if the telephone system is to be maintained. Due to the isolated location of the Indian office especially during winter months, it would seem advisable to retain a telephone service and we recommend that negotiations be undertaken as soon as possible with the Telephone Company so that the work can be put in hand before the Hydro line is energized.

Our officer discussed this matter with officers of the Indian Affairs Branch upon his return to Ottawa as it was considered an urgent matter requiring early attention.

(Sgd) Chas. H. Buck,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Ready,

The enclosed letters are self-explanatory. Neither girls seem to have courage to accept the position open to them. Self-confidence is often lacking in the Indian girls.

It was kind of you to consider the position as open to one of them and no doubt later when they have a little experience, they'll (apparently) appreciate your offer if there is still an opening.

I would appreciate much if Maymie could be given another year to complete her stenography. Edna had taken Gr. 1B work in Gordon River. Maymie tried but was often absent.

Re: Margaret Elliott

The above-mentioned girls are the daughters of Mrs. Elizabeth (George) Elliott, No. 318, Cape Croker Band.

Margaret was admitted in 1946 to the Convent of Immaculate Conception in Pembroke and I understand passed her examinations with honours.

Harriett has passed her examinations for entrance to High School this year and the grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McLeod of Wikwemikong, who have raised these children, would very much like Harriett to be with Margaret.

It has just come to my attention however, that Harriett has never been enrolled on the membership of Cape Croker Band due to the fact Mr. and Mrs. Elliott were separated at time of her birth.

I have written to both Agent Tuffnell and Mrs. Elliott with reference to having Harriett enrolled on the Band membership but Mrs. Elliott has never replied to my letter.

Will it be possible to secure a tuition grant for this child to attend High School this year pending her enrollment on the Band membership which I think cannot be denied her since the mother is a married woman and a Band member.

Dear Mr. Phalen,

I am addressing this letter directly to you in order that it may reach the proper authorities immediately. I hope you will not think me too presumptuous in doing so.

My daughter, Dorothy, who attended high school last year, is planning to continue this year. The Department last year gave her a $250.00 grant. We added $50.00 and were able to get her board for $30.00 a month. This year that is impossible on account of the rising cost of living. We shall have to pay $35.00 or $40.00 per month.

Last year the Department gave grants to seven pupils. This year only two are continuing with high school. Therefore, would the Department consider granting Dorothy $300.00 this year and we will pay $50.00.

Only this week was I notified of the increase in board so would appreciate an early reply. Thanking you.

Yours truly,
Mrs. Joseph V. Atkinson

I am enclosing the report on the four students from Cape Croker as you requested, and send also my apologies for being late in the matter.

Regarding the four students, the following notes may be of interest:

Attendance: As a rule, absence has been due to difficulties in getting down from the cape on Mondays. Apart from this, they seem to attend pretty regularly.

Dorothy: I am not worried particularly about Dorothy. She is a capable girl, able to hold her own, and will in all probability be quite successful in June.

Richard, a very quiet boy in class, is almost too quiet to engage himself. Would it be better to ever accomplish much in academic subjects is anyone's matter of conjecture, but his high standing in shop work is to be commended, and I would certainly recommend that he continue until June at least.

Voucher, Imperial Oil, $171.40,

Attached you will find the above certified for payment, which covers ten bbls. of heater fuel-oil for the Mission Indian Day School, Squaw Bay Village, Fort William Reserve.

The teacher, Miss. Harrett, had asked that the school residence be provided with an oil stove for heating by fuel-wood has never been satisfactory and is an inconvenience. The former teacher, Mrs. Osborne, had been obliged to live during the winter months at the Squaw Bay Hospital, which is an indication as to the coldness and dampness of the quarters.

To remedy this situation, I transferred the space heater oil stove from the vacant Pic I.D.S. to this school. The teacher is much more pleased with this arrangement and the living quarters are warmer and more liveable than heretofore. We already have authority to purchase fuel oil locally, as required, for the Lake Helen and Long Lake I.D. Schools, and would like to have similar authority to do so at this school and would like to hear from you at an early date, please.

Enc.

G. Burk, Indian Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your letter of Jan. 12th authorizes the purchase locally of fuel-oil required for heating purposes at the Mission Bay I.D.S., Fort William Reserve. As instructed, we shall before the next heating season arrives put in a requisition for that season's fuel-oil requirements for you to deal further with at that time.

Regarding your final paragraph as to the approximate extra expenditure to be incurred in using oil, this is rather difficult to estimate, especially with prices of oil and fuel wood both increasing. Perhaps you referred to the extra cost at the Mission Bay School and not all the Agency schools now using fuel oil. Admittedly, fuel oil is somewhat more expensive than wood, but it is much more satisfactory in its consistency and lack of trouble. On an average season, we might estimate that perhaps $25. to $35. extra would be involved in use of fuel oil, and this is not to mention to initial "investment" of $8. per barrel which we can obtain credit on of course upon reverting back to fuel wood.

J.J. Burk,
Indian Superintendent.

Mr. J. G. Burk, Indian Supt.,

Dear Sir:

We would appreciate it very much if you would grant us authorization to buy at least eight tons of coal for a jacket heater.

Here is the reason for making this request. Many children take their baths here even during the summer holidays; the parents would also like to do so as they have no accommodations at home. So, we thought it would be more convenient if we had always some hot water.

Hoping that you will give careful consideration to this request and thanking you.

Yours very truly,

"Sr. Mary Saint Martha, Principal"

Dept. of Mines and Resources, December 10th, 1947.
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Esmond Meness - School Pupil.

Mrs. Peter Meness, mother of Esmond Meness, has asked me to write you regarding extra assistance in the boarding of Esmond who is attending Grade IX of the Golden Lake Indian Day School.

Esmond Meness was sixteen years old on Sept. 24th 1947 and the Family Allowance for him was discontinued in November. While your division is now allowing Mrs. Meness the sum of Ten Dollars per month to assist her to board and cloth Esmond, she feels that even with this amount of assistance she will be unable to keep him in school after the Christmas holidays. I might mention that I checked with the teacher and find that his record both in attendance and studies is very good.

I would recommend that Mrs. Meness be allowed an additional Five dollars per month (making a total of Fifteen dollars per month) assistance, starting December 1st, 1947.

Yours very truly,

H. F. Huddy,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 13, 1947.

Mr. H.P. Ruddy, Indian Agent,
Golden Lake, Ontario.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 10th instant, it has been decided to increase the tuition grant for Esmond Meness from $10.00 to $15.00 a month, effective December 1st, 1947.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Sister Agnes of the Sacred Heart wrote to me as you requested. In reply, I wish to say that I took over the figuring out of the accounts for Indian girls this past September and my first letter was mailed to you a few weeks ago. Dear Sir:

As you know James Tenniscoe has been attending Grade X of the Golden Lake Indian Day School. He successfully completed this grade in June of this year, and, as this is the highest grade taught in the school here, he will have to attend some other school during the next term if he is to continue his education.

His intention was to continue his highschool studies but he now advises me that he would like to take a business course instead. James is a very clever boy and I would highly recommend that he be given every chance to continue his studies in some business college.

The full financial responsibility for his tuition will have to be borne by the Department as James' parents have separated and he has no home. While there are business colleges in this district (at Pembroke and Renfrew) I would recommend that James be sent to boarding school, and would prefer a school run by Christian Brothers. If the Department has any knowledge of such a school I would be pleased to receive information about it.

Yours very truly,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs:

I have for reference your letter dated August 25th regarding an application for the marginally meted Indian boy to attend St. Patrick's College at Ottawa.

As requested in your letter I am returning the completed application form for a tuition grant for him but I would like to make the following comment for the Department's information.

As you know Grades IX and X are being taught in the Indian Day School here and we expect to have five pupils (not counting this boy) attend Grade IX during the next term. All of these Indian children were successful in getting their High School entrance this year. I would suggest that this boy attend the Indian Day School here for the next two years and then complete his education at some other school. By that time he will be seventeen years old and will have a better idea just what further education he wants. At present his father claims that he is unable to contribute anything towards his tuition, board and etc. If he is placed in St. Patrick's school but I think that with some help from the Department he would be able to keep him at home and have him attend the school here.

Yours very truly,

H. P. Ruddy,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I wish to advise you that the following Indian children have successfully passed their High School Entrance and are attending Grade IX at the Golden Lake Indian Day School.

Elizabeth Jecke - age 14 years, daughter of William Jecke.
Wanita Lavalley - age 14 years, daughter of James Lavalley.
Catherine Vincent - age 15 years, daughter of Samuel Vincent.
Anna Menes - age 14 years, daughter of Peter Menes.
Donald Sarazin - age 15 years, son of Daniel Sarazin.

One other Indian boy (Andrew Lavalley) also got his High School entrance but has stepped school.

The parents of these children are all in straitened circumstances financially and have to depend on part-time labour for their existence, and all of them, with the exception of one (James Lavalley) have large families to support. Therefore I would ask the Department to assist the parents of each of these children to the amount of $10.00 per month during the school term to help feed and clothe them. This amount could be given to the parents in cash at the end of each month or given to them as one ration in groceries from a local store.

I know that this assistance which will amount to $500.00 for the school year 1950-51 is quite an expenditure to ask the Department to make, but I feel that it would be worth while so that these children may have a chance to further their education. Without this assistance I am afraid that their parents will not be able to keep them in school.

Yours very truly,

H. P. Ruddy, Indian Agent.

I.A.B. File 45-13.

We are having some difficulty in arranging for the purchase of this coal, which is in short supply at this point and elsewhere on Great Lakes ports, due to seamen's strikes. Three firms have expressed their willingness to supply our requirements if and when they can guarantee delivery and prices.

Coal Control Board officials have suggested that if U.S. anthracite is not available in the near future at Sault Ste Marie, Ontario, it may be necessary to consider Canadian western fuel, in which case it might be well to have Mr. Laurence's advice as to the grade of coal or coke, or briquettes most suitable for the heating equipment at the above school.

I wish to acknowledge your letter 45-13 (WT1) dated August 27th enclosing a copy of a memorandum received from the Purchasing Agent regarding coal for the Garden River R.C. School.

I am advised that there is no western fuel in Sault Ste. Marie and also that western fuel would not be suitable for the type of heating at the Garden River School, as the heating plant consists of coal stoves in each room and soft coal would be too dirty and smoky, also not suitable for the cook stove in the kitchen.

Smale Bros. Coal dealers of Sault Ste. Marie advise me that they expect to have anthracite in a month's time and could then supply our requirements. They have suggested that permission be received from the Coal Control Board to allow the 15 tons of anthracite required put in at one time, as it would be hard to supply this school during the winter months.

Moravian Indian Day School.

Reference your of February 26.

It is noted that the second classroom at the above school is now ready for a teacher. With regard to the platform suggested, I would advise that modern classrooms have dispensed with this type of platform. However, we are quite prepared to authorized the expenditure if the blackboard is too high. I would recommend that this matter be left in abeyance until the teacher is appointed and we can allow her to decide whether she wants a platform. If she does, then you can proceed to have the necessary expenditure made for this installation.

With regard to the janitor, authority is granted to make the payment of $250.00 per year for his duties in both classrooms. This new salary will become effective from the date that the second classroom is opened. You can submit the usual voucher quoting this letter as authority.

With regard to the teacher please find attached an application form which you can have Mrs. Wootton complete if she so desires. Based on the information in your letter, she would be entitled to a salary of $150.00 per teaching month. If she will be handling only grades one and two in the second classroom, then she can dismiss these children at 2:30 or 3 o'clock. This would allow her to return home in time to get supper etc. It is presumed that Mr. Dodson dismissed the younger children at this earlier hour at the present time.
I will expect to hear further from you with regard to Mrs. Wootton as teacher, as the one we had in mind for you is now employed at another of our Indian Day Schools.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Conley,

Just a few lines hoping you are well. You remember my husband was in the last war, well he Jim is in the army again. He is somewhere over home in Scotland landed 28th Feb. safely things are pretty quiet on the reserve. I heard D'Stone is in the army. Dear Sir:

I have your letter of June the 18th, asking for more explanations in regard to non-treaty Indians attending schools who are not furnished books by the Teachers.

In both the Maniwaki Indian Day School and the Congo Bridge there, white and non treaty Indians attending School who are not furnished school supplies.

At the Maniwaki Indian Day School we have about 10 non-treaty Indians attending School who are not furnished with school supplies, there are also a few white children going there, but there is no question of furnishing them with School supplies.

At the Congo Bridge Day School there are a couple of non-treaty Indians there who are not supposed to receive school supplies. Two or three white children attending that school are not receiving school supplies and there is no question of furnishing them with some. The trouble is mostly at the Maniwaki Indian Day School. Those non-treaty Indians claim they are entitled to school supplies as well as the members of the River Desert Band.

Your obedient servant,

October 28, 1943.

Mrs. Joe James Comanda was in the office today with a letter she received from the Nuns of the Sacred Heart Convent, Château Avenue, Ottawa East, telling her that the cost of feeding her two girls would be $5.00 a month for the two.

It seems that Mrs. Comanda through the Oblate Fathers has written to this convent to accept her two little girls, Florence 10 and Jeannette 8. She claims that her husband is working at Hotel City, New York and that she just came back from there. Here she has employed. When she has settled her business she expects to go back to work there. She also claims that with the salary they are getting they can afford to take their children in the Convent and make the Department to pay each month for this cost and they will gradually refund it to the Department.

What I know about Gladys Joe James Comanda is that he is not very good for anything, does not look after his property and has purchased one lot which he did not own and sold it to two different people. Besides that he never took good care of his family, and when they were living around here, Comanda was always looked in the office to have her husband fined for non-support. Owing to these facts I cannot recommend to the Department to advance anything to this Joe James Comanda's family, but would suggest that they look after their children and the other Indians.

Dear Mr. Johnson,

In response to your letter of January 26th, I have to inform you that the above girl is attending school at our mission, Mrs. Joe Louis on the Mowat Indian Reserve. She is well taken care of at present, but I am not against the idea of sending her to a residential school. Her religion is Catholic.

Mrs. Louis is very poor herself and although she gets a lot of help from her daughter, Louise, it may prove a strain having no mother to guide her. It will be hard to control her.

For your own information I wish to explain that Mary Louise, as born when Alonso Comanche left his wife. She really is not a Comanche but last year was enrolled on the list, as the father is not known and has always carried the name of Comanche. The mother is Mrs. Alonso Comanche who is now in St. Joseph's Home in Ottawa.

Should it be necessary that she should go to a residential school, I will immediately get in touch with her in order to find out if she really wants to go or not.

A.

Mr. J.E. Gendron, Indian Agent, Maniwaki, Que.

I have your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to Mary Louise Commons and I note that you consider that she is receiving reasonable care at the present time and presumably you approve her remaining with her stepsister, Mrs. Joseph Jacko, for the time being at least.

On receipt of your letter we checked the quarterly returns from the Congo Bridge and Maniwaki Day Schools for the past two and a half years and we cannot find this girl's name entered. It would, therefore, appear that she is not attending school. Dear Sir:

Would you kindly take into consideration the following request, and, please, introduce it to the Indian Department, if you think it becoming.

You probably do know that Jimmy Commanda, Michel's son, has placed his two daughters as boarders, in the Sacred Heart Sisters' Convent, (Avenue des Oblats, Ottawa). Jimmy and his wife have placed their two children there in the autumn of 1943; and up to December 1944, (inclusively) have been faithful to pay the boarding expenses, as it is certified by the included certificate, signed by the Principal of that School.

But, unfortunately, as you know, and is indicated on the X-Ray report, the parents of those girls are both suspected of tuberculosis, and ordered by the physician, Doctor Lecuyer, to give up any work for a period of a few months, at least. Consequently, they are now unable to pay their daughters' boarding charges.

As I am very interested in the Indians' education and moral progress, and especially in the moral life of the Indian girls, who will the future Indian mothers, and as, on the other hand, I know very well, the marvelous moral, intellectual and educational progress realized by the Commanda's girls, since their entering in that boarding school, I would deeply regret to see them leave from there. Therefore, I consider it my duty to ask you kindly to introduce to the Indian Branches Affairs, my request that the said Department accept to cover the girls' boarding expenses for the present school year, that is from January 1945 up to June 1945, inclusively.
Would you please draw the attention of the Department upon the following reasons, on which I base my statement:

1. That any change of school would require a new adaptation as to environments, teachers and program, and would therefore cause the girls a real delay and damage.

2. That the cost of their boarding, school, dresses and books together, is rather low. (twenty-20 dollars a month for each of them).

3. That their coming back at home would bring a surplus of work to their convalescent mother, and might also place the girls in danger of contracting the same lung trouble.

4. That in whatever place they will study and be boarded, it will be at the Indians' Department's charges.

In the hope that the Indians' Department will see the ground of those reasons, and take my request into consideration, I thank you in advance for your collaboration, and I remain,

Yours truly,

M. Baker:

En réponse à la votre du 19 courant,
il me fait plaisir de vous faire parvenir les renseignements
demandés au sujet de Messieurs Jean et Joseph Brascoupe.

Nous sommes très satisfaits de ces deux
écoliers tant pour leur conduite que pour leur application
au travail.

Jean a conservé 82,3% aux examens de juin
dernier et 74% sur le trimestre. Joseph a conservé 80% aux
examens et 81% sur le trimestre. Ils sont promus tous les
deux. Jean entrera en Philosophie 2e, c'est-à-dire qu'il
terminera son cours classique cette année. Joseph sera en

heureux de les recevoir.

J'ose croire que ces quelques renseignements
répondront à votre demande.

Je demeure bien votre en N. Seigneur,

I enclose herewith in triplicate a requisition covering fuel requirements for eleven Day Schools in this Agency for the year ending March 31, 1949.

The fuel wood will all be purchased from Indians and the coal from Mrs. J.N. Sisson of Little Current.

I would also point out that the amounts of coal required and the prices are only approximate. This is the first time to use coal for heating schools in this Agency and the prices are subject to change.

During Mr. Doucet's visit to the Agency, we called on Mrs. Sisson, the only coal dealer on the Island, and found that she has not previously been handling the type of coal (pea size) desired for use at Lakeview School. I understand however, that she will endeavour to get it for us but will probably require us to take a small car load.

The sisters at Wikwemikong are in urgent need of fuel wood and I would request that an advance cheque be forwarded at the earliest convenience to make payment in the usual way.

C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,

Re: Lakeview Indian Day School

With reference to fuel for heating, I have been making enquiries and find there are no dealers on the Island who stock Buckwheat or Rice White Ash Anthracite.

Orchard Fuels of Little Current advise me they are familiar with the Volcano Stoker it is proposed to install at this school and that pea size will give satisfactory service but that it is more expensive than the smaller size. They quote $22.10 per ton on pea size anthracite delivered to the School and have a considerable amount in stock.

They will however supply the other sizes in carload Lots delivered to the school at the following prices:

No. 1 Buckwheat - Pittston - $17.67 per ton
Rice Coal Pittston or Lichens Valley - 16.66 per ton

There is no guarantee however of the size of car we might get. Forty or fifty tons is considered a small car and storage for this amount of coal would be quite a problem so that I would suggest using the pea size coal provided it is considered satisfactory for the stoker to be installed.

C. R. Johnston,

I would prefer to get the coal for Murray Hill from Orchard Fuels also as they make their own deliveries and will do it more economical.

Mrs. Sisson does not make delivery outside of Little Current and we have to make our own arrangements for delivery.

Practically all the wood will be purchased from Indians.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

With reference to the attached requisition for coal, Superintendent Johnston writes as follows:

"The price of coal for Murray Hill School is from Mrs. J.N. Sisson, Little Current and for Lakewiew School from Orchard Fuels, Little Current, and is a delivered price. This firm advises they expect the price may be slightly lower by the time delivery is taken but has quoted present day prices. I would prefer to get the coal for Murray Hill from Orchard Fuels also as they make their own deliveries and will do it more economical.

Mrs. Sisson does not make delivery outside of Little Current and we have to make our own arrangements for delivery."

Bernard F. Neary,
